questions.neutral: You're not here by accident, are you?

hobby.message: You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Just needed a quiet place.
I spend time repairing old typewriters, nothing unusual.
Hard to focus lately with all the neighborhood changes.
If you hear keys, it's only me working.
Not by accident, no. Needed a break from home noise.
I restore antique typewriters—more habit than hobby nowadays.
Courtyard's been louder since those broadcasts began.
Harder to find calm with everyone on edge lately.
People stare when they hear keys clacking.
Not exactly an accident. Needed space for my head to clear.
I like to restore and write on old typewriters, keeps my hands steady.
Lately, crowds in my building watch Rada’s coverage and debate all evening.
Sometimes I move my typewriter closer to the window to listen, even if I can't concentrate.
People are quick to notice anything different nowadays.
Strange how a hobby that helped me stay unnoticed now draws glances.
I came here to escape the debates swirling in my building.
Antique typewriters are my passion—maintenance, repair, even a little writing.
Usually, the mechanical rhythm settles my mind—never fails.
But these days, with Rada's broadcasts and the free zones, it's all different.
Last week, I tried to type as neighbors chanted for self-rule beneath my window.
The system used to ignore a quiet hobby like mine. Not anymore.
Even a ribbon change gets you noticed if you aren't careful.
No accident. Needed a break from the neighborhood’s sudden hunger for democracy.
I’ve collected, restored, and written on antique typewriters since before Halden digitized everything.
Used to be, people barely noticed. Now, the click of keys makes them curious or suspicious.
Last week, as Rada's broadcasts stirred the block, my typewriter felt almost rebellious.
I found myself typing commentary just for the rhythm, half hoping the noise would blend with their chants.
These days, hobbies like mine mark you as eccentric or worse—especially if your BCI ticks down.
I keep my machines in perfect order, each one a remnant of quieter times.
Funny—after all these years, I trust typebars more than most people.
hobby_answer: Still tuning. Keeps me occupied, you know.
Some things work better unplugged from all this.
No shortage of distractions lately. Makes focusing tricky.
Machines don't worry about BCI outages.
Lately, not many quiet evenings left for it.
Yep, still at it. Few typewriters left these days.
Makes less noise than most hobbies. Safe enough if you stay inside.
Recently, harder to get supplies. Courier delays, restrictions.
Hard to concentrate when the building's on manual approval.
Too many people watching each other. Even hobbies feel different now.
Typed pages never show up in leaks.
I do. Always something to adjust or restore.
Iron ribbon, mechanical escapement... little triumphs when city feels uncertain.
Got interrupted last week: that neighborhood disconnect—the one everyone talked about.
People gathered under my window listening to broadcasts, debating, yelling.
Hard to keep your hands steady with all that.
Made me write about the scene instead. History on paper, at least.
Hobby feels odd with so much change out there.
Oh, yes—still tuning them, especially the older models from the '60s.
I keep the Imperial ready, just in case ink ribbons disappear again.
Last Thursday, couldn't focus—everyone outside glued to Rada's reports.
Feels strange writing while the street votes on water and curfews.
Used to be just me and my keys. This week, the whole block felt it.
Sometimes I document the noise, not just thoughts.
Supply shops closed after the leaks. Had to improvise with old carbon ribbons.
Even so, a clean mechanical line on the page settles the nerves.
Absolutely. Still got my Model 75 from years ago, works smoother than most modern systems.
Takes me three hours to tune the escapement right—worth every second for a clean line.
Since Halden’s death, and now those breakaway districts, nothing feels routine.
Neighbors meeting outside during Rada’s coverage—could hear every word through thin walls.
Last Saturday, had to draft by candlelight—new resource rules delayed power for flagged residencies.
Feels absurd, fixing machines while the city questions who runs it.
Sometimes I jot down names, overheard arguments—a record nobody else keeps now.
Strange comfort to know a keystroke can’t be ghosted.
Honestly, these days, typewriter ink holds firmer memory than any BCI data ever did.
